DataElement.preferredName: Past 4 Week Daily Protective Clothing Use Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Numeric code response to a question about the number of pads or adult diapers typically used per day by a person to control leakage during the previous four weeks.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Urine Leakage Adult Diaper Use Frequency
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The fluid that is excreted by the kidneys.  It is stored in the bladder and discharged through the urethra._The unwanted discharge of a fluid from some container or vessel._The number of occurrences of something within a given time period. (NCI)_A human who has reached reproductive age._A barrier garment or padding used to absorb urine and stool, thereby helping to protect the skin and keep clothing and bedding clean.__Use; put into service; make work or employ (something) for a particular purpose or for its inherent or natural purpose.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The fluid that is excreted by the kidneys.  It is stored in the bladder and discharged through the urethra.:The unwanted discharge of a fluid from some container or vessel.

Concepts.definition: The fluid that is excreted by the kidneys.  It is stored in the bladder and discharged through the urethra.
The unintentional discharge of a substance from a container or enclosed space.

Property.preferredDefinition: A human who has reached reproductive age.:A barrier garment or padding used to absorb urine and stool, thereby helping to protect the skin and keep clothing and bedding clean.:Use; put into service; make work or employ (something) for a particular purpose or for its inherent or natural purpose.:The number of occurrences of something within a given time period. Concepts.definition: An age group comprised of humans who have reached reproductive age.
A barrier garment or padding used to absorb urine and stool, thereby helping to protect the skin and keep clothing and bedding clean.
A manner, or usual, or accepted practice of using something.
The number of occurrences of something within a given time period.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Past; before the present time._A number with no fractional part.::4_Any period of seven consecutive days.__Occurring or done each day._Clothing designed to protect the individual against possible exposure to known hazards._Use; put into service; make work or employ (something) for a particular purpose or for its inherent or natural purpose._A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A subjective response indicating that an individual uses or used three absorbent pads per day.

Concepts.longName: Three or More Pads per Day
Concepts.definition: A subjective response indicating that an individual uses or used three or more absorbent pads per day.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A subjective response indicating that an individual uses or used two absorbent pads per day.

Concepts.definition: A subjective response indicating that an individual uses or used two absorbent pads per day.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A subjective response indicating that an individual uses or used one absorbent pad per day.

Concepts.definition: A subjective response indicating that an individual uses or used one absorbent pad per day.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

Concepts.definition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

Concepts.definition: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
Clothing designed to protect the individual against possible exposure to known hazards.
A manner, or usual, or accepted practice of using something.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.

ReferenceDocuments.name: How many pads or adult diaper
ReferenceDocuments.description: How many pads or adult diapers per day did you usually use to control leakage during the last 4 weeks?
